abstract: An effort to let shareholders hire and fire directors directly. | A Pritzker dreams of empire. | Businesses assess impact of G.O.P. victory. | Einhorn gives up on Green Mountain.
snippet: An effort to let shareholders hire and fire directors directly. | A Pritzker dreams of empire. | Businesses assess impact of G.O.P. victory. | Einhorn gives up on Green Mountain.
lead_paragraph: Annual shareholder meetings are supposed to allow a company’s owners to change troubling governance practices. But in reality, most of these meetings and the shareholder votes that are cast at them give outside investors little say on oversight of a company’s board, as the current director election system in the United States allows board members to win or hold their seats even if they do not receive support from a majority of shareholder votes cast, Gretchen Morgenson writes in The New York Times. Now, a band of institutional shareholders is looking to change what they see as a dysfunctional dynamic. Led by Scott M. Stringer, the New York City comptroller and a Democrat, the group is mounting the first push ever at 75 United States companies to allow investors to hire and fire directors directly.

headline.main: Morning Agenda: Seeking More Say on Directors

abstract: The settlement followed a whistle-blower lawsuit that asserted the company had induced physicians to use its devices by paying them inflated fees.
snippet: The settlement followed a whistle-blower lawsuit that asserted the company had induced physicians to use its devices by paying them inflated fees.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department said on Thursday that a producer of heart implants, Biotronik, had agreed to pay $4.9 million to resolve claims that it paid kickbacks to physicians to use its devices. The settlement followed a whistle-blower lawsuit filed by a former Biotronik employee, Brian Sant, who said that the company had induced physicians to use its pacemakers and defibrillators through methods like paying them inflated fees to serve on a company advisory board. The company did not acknowledge wrongdoing. In 2011, The New York Times published an article documenting an unusual pattern in the growth of Biotronik devices in some Western states. In Las Vegas, for example, the article reported that surgeons at a major hospital switched to using almost exclusively the company’s devices soon after being put on its payroll as consultants. The Justice Department said its settlement with Biotronik covered the company’s activities in Nevada and Arizona.

headline.main: Biotronik to Pay $4.9 Million to Settle Kickback Claims
headline.print_headline: Biotronik to Pay $4.9. Million to Settle Kickback Claims

Transocean said the charges forced it to delay its third-quarter earnings report, which was scheduled for Friday. Companies that explore for and produce oil are cutting back on investment because of sharp declines in the price of oil, which is reducing demand for rigs and lowering rates for Transocean’s equipment. Brent crude, the most common benchmark for global oil, has fallen 28 percent since late June.

abstract: Everyone told our new blogger she should go for it, and she went for it. And then the growth stopped. Now she is re-thinking everything, which is what she will be writing about.

lead_paragraph: In 2001, my husband and I ditched the dot-com rat race of Silicon Valley for a more peaceful life in the mountains of Lake Tahoe. As burned-out software engineers, we had grand visions of trading our keyboards for snowboards, our motorcycles for bicycles, and taking the trail instead of taking BART. To help support our new lifestyle, we invested our savings ($30,000) and opened Jimmy Beans Wool, a 500 square-foot yarn shop in Reno, Nev.

lead_paragraph: Our puzzle this week was suggested by Marco Moriconi, a regular Numberplay contributor and professor of physics at the Universidade Federal Fluminense, in Niteroi, Rio de Janeiro. (He also writes a monthly math column for the Brazilian national science magazine, Ciência Hoje (Science Today), called Qual o Problema, or “What’s the Problem?”). Dr. Moriconi found this week’s puzzle in a blog by its creator, Roy Cook, a professor of philosophy at the University of Minnesota who tells how he momentarily stumped the famous paradox master Raymond Smullyan with the challenge. abstract: The beleaguered retailer said sales fell 5 percent in the third quarter and losses grew as it reeled from the firing of its chief executive, Dov Charney, in June.
snippet: The beleaguered retailer said sales fell 5 percent in the third quarter and losses grew as it reeled from the firing of its chief executive, Dov Charney, in June.
lead_paragraph: American Apparel, a beleaguered retailer still wincing from a boardroom struggle over the summer, said sales fell 5 percent in the third quarter and losses grew — dragged down in no small part by its own investigation of the behavior of Dov Charney, who was fired as chief executive in June. The company, which has been without a permanent chief executive ever since, reported a net loss of $19.2 million, or 11 cents a share, most of which was nonrecurring costs, including $5.3 million in legal and other costs connected to Mr. Charney’s departure. A year ago, the net loss was $1.5 million. Net sales in the third quarter slipped to $155.9 million, compared with $164.5 million last year. Highlighting the company’s adjusted earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization, which jumped 38 percent to $13.5 million, Scott Brubaker, the interim chief, said in a statement, “I am encouraged by these results, and am optimistic about the future prospects of the business.”

headline.main: Investigation of Charney Adds to Loss at American Apparel

lead_paragraph: As authorities in the United States and Britain ready actions this week against giant banks suspected of manipulating the foreign currency market, banks are facing tougher settlement language and bigger fines than expected, Ben Protess and Jenny Anderson write in DealBook. The banks learned on Monday that the Commodity Futures Trading Commission in Washington was planning to announce its own settlements in the case, ending weeks of suspense over whether the agency would act in coordination with British authorities and United States banking regulators. The agency is expected to level around $300 million in fines against each of the banks, with the worst offenders paying slightly more and marginal players somewhat less.

lead_paragraph: COW WOW CEREAL MILK is a two-year-old  company that makes milk in breakfast cereal flavors. Founded by Christopher Pouy, a former advertising copywriter seeking to capitalize on a childhood love, it is based in Los Angeles and employs 10. By putting a child-friendly cow on the package and giving his flavors names like Fruity Trudy and Chocolate Chip Cathy, Mr. Pouy branded his product for 5- to 12-year-olds.

lead_paragraph: The settlements by five global banks for manipulating the foreign currency markets show a strategy based on strength in numbers: The more banks that are disciplined, the less any one of them will be the focus of public attention for their violations. lead_paragraph: For many start-ups, a website is just the business’s online presence, a place to be found. For other start-ups, however, the website is the business. abstract: Net neutrality could give Comcast a way out of its Time Warner Cable acquisition. | Warren E. Buffett’s deal for Duracell satisfies a number of his deal-making preferences. | Virgin America to begin trading. | Goldman seeks to lure tech talent.

lead_paragraph: NET NEUTRALITY COULD AFFECT COMCAST’S DEAL | Comcast’s $45 billion deal for Time Warner Cable may have seemed like a good idea earlier this year. But now that President Obama has endorsed net neutrality, Comcast might have buyer’s remorse, Steven Davidoff Solomon writes in the Deal Professor column. Given how much detractors have urged the Federal Communications Commission to reject the deal, Comcast may now find, ironically, that the only way out is to have the F.C.C. block the transaction. “This F.C.C. battle all comes down to whether bigger in and of itself is a problem, and President Obama’s statements only add to the troubles for this deal,” Mr. Davidoff Solomon writes.

headline.main: Morning Agenda: Net Neutrality’s Effect on Comcast

abstract: Wall Street is on pace for a big year of deal-making. | William A. Ackman may have lost Allergan, but he still came away a winner. | The Justice Department is weighing a civil suit against Angelo R. Mozilo, the former chief executive of Countrywide Financial. | U.S. plans second Bitcoin auction.
snippet: Wall Street is on pace for a big year of deal-making. | William A. Ackman may have lost Allergan, but he still came away a winner. | The Justice Department is weighing a civil suit against Angelo R. Mozilo, the former chief executive of Countrywid...
lead_paragraph: RETURN OF THE MEGA-MERGER | Mega-mergers are back. Mergers worth $100 billion, made on Monday, put Wall Street on pace for a year of deal-making rivaling those during the dot-com bubble and the private equity upsurge just before the financial crisis, DealBook’s David Gelles writes. The announcement of two mega-deals ‒ Actavis’s $66 billion acquisition of the Botox maker Allergan and Halliburton’s $34.6 billion takeover of the oil field services firm Baker Hughes ‒ made Monday a symbolic tipping point, Mr. Gelles writes. With those transactions, about $1.5 trillion in deals targeting United States companies have been announced this year, the most since 2000, according to Thomson Reuters.

headline.main: Morning Agenda: Return of the Mega-Merger

lead_paragraph: Jen Boulden was a serial start-up entrepreneur before she decided to go back to school for a master’s degree in  environmental policy and management at George Washington University, in 2004. That same year, she co-founded a daily green-lifestyle email subscription service, Ideal Bite, sold four years later to Disney with 318,000 daily subscribers, for $20 million. abstract: The release of an interview Robert Rubin gave nine years ago offers a window into the thoughts of the rich and powerful, William D. Cohan writes in the Street Scene column.
snippet: The release of an interview Robert Rubin gave nine years ago offers a window into the thoughts of the rich and powerful, William D. Cohan writes in the Street Scene column.
lead_paragraph: For the last 25 years or so, Robert E. Rubin, a former co-senior partner at Goldman Sachs when it was a private partnership, has played an inordinately important role in Washington. Some of his extraordinary influence has been overt, as when he served President Clinton as head of the National Economic Council and then as Treasury secretary, and some of it has been subtler but no less significant. For instance, his fingerprints are all over the Obama administration’s cabinet and its economic team: Timothy F. Geithner, Lawrence H. Summers, Peter R. Orszag, Gene B. Sperling, Jason Furman, Jacob J. Lew, Michael Froman and Sylvia Mathews Burwell at one time or another have had — or still have — close ties to Mr. Rubin.

headline.main: A First-Person History Lesson From Robert Rubin

abstract: China cuts benchmark interest rates for the first time since July 2012. | Fed to review bank oversight. | Sotheby’s chief to step down. | Goldman and Senate spar over commodities.

lead_paragraph: CHINA CUTS RATES | China has cut benchmark interest rates for the first time since July 2012, Bloomberg News reports. The one-year deposit rate was lowered by 0.25 percentage points to 2.75 percent, while the one-year lending rate was reduced by 0.4 percentage points to 5.6 percent, effective on Saturday, the People’s Bank of China said on its website on Friday. The move is a departure for the People’s Bank of China, which had focused on selective monetary easing and liquidity injections as the country heads for its slowest full-year growth since 1990. European stocks and United States stock index futures were higher after the announcement. ​

headline.main: Morning Agenda: China Cuts Rates

abstract: Despite drawbacks, some immigrants working in technology said the president’s actions could make work in the United States easier.

abstract: Last week was a rough one for the Federal Reserve. | Paul J. Taubman continues to poach talent from Morgan Stanley, his former employer. | Mathew Martoma has started his nine-year prison term for insider trading.
snippet: Last week was a rough one for the Federal Reserve. | Paul J. Taubman continues to poach talent from Morgan Stanley, his former employer. | Mathew Martoma has started his nine-year prison term for insider trading.
lead_paragraph: ROUGH WEEK REVEALS CHALLENGES FOR THE FED | Last week was not a good one for the Federal Reserve, but it wasn’t so bad for anyone interested in understanding how the secretive institution works, Gretchen Morgenson writes in the Fair Game column. “It was fascinating to learn last week that the Fed is embarking on a soul-searching campaign,” she writes. Its inspector general will take up the “astonishing questions of whether the Fed’s big-bank examiners have what they need to do their jobs and whether they receive the support of their superiors when they challenge bank practices.”

headline.main: Morning Agenda: Challenges for the Fed

abstract: The Fed has to balance the conflicting roles it plays as an overseer of the banks and as a law enforcement agency pursuing misconduct, Peter J. Henning writes in the White Collar Watch column.
snippet: The Fed has to balance the conflicting roles it plays as an overseer of the banks and as a law enforcement agency pursuing misconduct, Peter J. Henning writes in the White Collar Watch column.
lead_paragraph: Unlike the happy ending for George Bailey, the banker in “It’s a Wonderful Life,” last week was not pleasant for Wall Street banks and their primary regulator, the Federal Reserve. Pilloried at congressional hearings and the subject of a report in The New York Times about leaked confidential information, the Fed faces the question of whether it can ever hope to effectively control these giant financial institutions.

abstract: The British fixed-line giant has a choice of two mobile networks to buy, O2 or EE, and few likely counterbidders, says Quentin Webb of Reuters Breakingviews.
snippet: The British fixed-line giant has a choice of two mobile networks to buy, O2 or EE, and few likely counterbidders, says Quentin Webb of Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: BT is in a strong position for mobile mergers and acquisitions. It has shaken up British communications by moving into television and by preparing to start a novel mobile service of its own. Now the fixed-line giant finds itself with a choice of two wireless networks to buy, Telefónica’s O2 unit or Orange and Deutsche Telekom’s EE. There are few likely counter-bidders for either potential target.

It was Hamilton’s second drivers championship victory; he had also won the 2008 championship title. He lost the 2007 championship by a single point.

headline.main: Monday Motorsports: Hamilton Wins Formula One Title

abstract: Morgan Downey is chief executive of Money.Net, a financial start-up. On one flight, he awoke to find a seatmate taking food off his plate.
snippet: Morgan Downey is chief executive of Money.Net, a financial start-up. On one flight, he awoke to find a seatmate taking food off his plate.
lead_paragraph: I WAS born and raised in Ireland. I graduated from university on a Saturday and took my first overseas flight the next day to New York City where I was going to start a job as a commodities trader. I remember landing at J.F.K. airport, getting off the plane, and walking through some sliding glass doors to get my first glimpse of America. There was this weird déjà vu moment like I had seen America before, but I think that was just due to all the American television I watched growing up, with shows like the “The A-Team,” “Star Trek,” “The Six Million Dollar Man,” “Sesame Street” and “Beverly Hills 90210” shaping my perception of the United States. But I still couldn’t believe how big the cars were.

headline.main: Handling a Thief in Business Class
headline.print_headline: Handling a Thief in Business Class

abstract: Weight Watchers is taking a celebrity-free approach to advertising with its new campaign, focusing on people’s tendency to seek solace in calories.
snippet: Weight Watchers is taking a celebrity-free approach to advertising with its new campaign, focusing on people’s tendency to seek solace in calories.
lead_paragraph: FOR an industry that aims to help change consumers’ habits, weight-loss brands themselves seem to take the same approach year in and year out: Hire celebrities who have lost weight through the programs to pitch them. But now Weight Watchers, which featured Jessica Simpson in advertising earlier this year, is introducing a campaign that ditches the celebrity approach.

abstract: If Republicans wanted to pass an immigration overhaul, they would do so, regardless of whether President Obama were being confrontational.

lead_paragraph: There are certainly some serious critiques of President Obama’s new immigration policy. It could encourage more illegal immigration in the long run. It may be another step toward an imperial presidency, detached from Congress. It definitely could have been executed less cynically, given that Mr. Obama all but admitted he delayed the announcement until after the midterms, in an (unsuccessful) effort to help Democrats on the ballot.

abstract: To combat declining attendance, movie theaters are experimenting with more immersive and interactive experiences, including moving seats, scents and precipitation.
snippet: To combat declining attendance, movie theaters are experimenting with more immersive and interactive experiences, including moving seats, scents and precipitation.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Having tried 3-D films, earsplitting sound systems and even alcohol sales in pursuit of younger moviegoers, some theater chains are now installing undulating seats, scent machines and 270-degree screens.

headline.main: To Lure Young, Movie Theaters Shake, Smell and Spritz
headline.print_headline: To Lure Young, Theaters Shake, Smell and Spritz

abstract: Sony Pictures Entertainment is investigating what provoked the cyberattack, including whether there are any ties to a coming film that has elicited the ire of North Korea.
snippet: Sony Pictures Entertainment is investigating what provoked the cyberattack, including whether there are any ties to a coming film that has elicited the ire of North Korea.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — While rivals focused on the holiday box office, Sony Pictures Entertainment spent Thanksgiving weekend coping with the continuing effects of a cyberattack — and investigating what provoked the onslaught, including whether there were any ties to a coming comedy that has elicited the ire of North Korea.

headline.main: Intrusion on Sony Unit Prompts a Shutdown of Messaging Systems
headline.print_headline: Intrusion on Sony Unit Prompts a Shutdown of Messaging Systems

byline.original: By Brooks Barnes and Michael Cieply

abstract: Matt Ginsberg does us a tremendous favor.
snippet: Matt Ginsberg does us a tremendous favor.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — I spent a good part of my early career in advertising, and I was always amazed at how hard the media department worked to make sure that the clients’ products got in front of the television-viewing audience.

headline.main: Zap!

abstract: Initial weak numbers revived concerns among retailers that, despite improved economic conditions, shoppers remain wary.
snippet: Initial weak numbers revived concerns among retailers that, despite improved economic conditions, shoppers remain wary.
lead_paragraph: Even as more stores opened their doors on Thanksgiving, hoping for a jump start to the holiday season, an initial reading suggested that combined sales on Thanksgiving and Black Friday fell 0.5 percent from the same period last year.

headline.main: Black Friday Sales Slip as Discounts Start Earlier
headline.print_headline: Black Friday Sales Slip as Discounts Start Earlier

abstract: The visionary who stares at formulas written on walls or mirrors — or better yet, thin air — has become a Hollywood trope. So has the depiction of the genius who can’t connect with real people.
snippet: The visionary who stares at formulas written on walls or mirrors — or better yet, thin air — has become a Hollywood trope. So has the depiction of the genius who can’t connect with real people.
lead_paragraph: Math movies have become a dependable genre. There is a shot of a genius staring rapturously at mind-bending numbers. He is an insufferable person. There will be much drama about whether he can learn to value human emotion over cold fact.

headline.main: Math Anxiety: Why Hollywood Makes Robots of Alan Turing and Other Geniuses

abstract: John Guzzetta and his puzzle adore us. That’s a nice way to start our solving week.
snippet: John Guzzetta and his puzzle adore us. That’s a nice way to start our solving week.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — What better way to start our solving week than with a message from an ADORING constructor?

headline.main: Take Part in a Buddy System

abstract: Inc. is becoming a mainstream publication, turning out glossy covers that broaden its appeal.
snippet: Inc. is becoming a mainstream publication, turning out glossy covers that broaden its appeal.
lead_paragraph: For many years, Inc. was a magazine that featured obscure entrepreneurs and quirky start-ups on its covers.

headline.main: Long Overshadowed in Realm of Business Magazines, Inc. Grabs the Spotlight
headline.print_headline: Long Overshadowed in Realm of Business Magazines, Inc. Grabs the Spotlight
